content: Really enjoyed this for what it was but thought it was far too short and a bit of an anti-climax. Fun while it lasted though
Frustrating. Had to look up many of the answers. Re-read the story and still did not understand it. Wasted both money and time.
Enjoyed playing for a little while, but then, like for the last reviewer, it got stuck and didn't accept it a word that was correct (I checked it online). Frustrating.
Really enjoyed this quirky game. Great way to kill an hour.

It is intriguing but unfortunately buggy. Very short way into the game I was unable to progress as it would not accept the solution. I even checked up online and confirmed that this was the correct word. Would love to read this story away from the game format.
It doesn't work on my android
Great story, poor gaming experience.

On the whole quite enjoyable and captivating, if a little short. My only complaint was that there were a couple of puzzles, for lack of a better word, that almost necessarily needed to be looked up. Aside from that, however, I found it both entertaining and intriguing.
I put in a word, but it gets rejected, so I try other words. No luck. So I try the first one again--and now it works. Stupid game.
It's useless. A bit sad. üòî

A demonstration of a mechanic that has a lot of potential, but sadly that potential isn't exhibited here. Most of the game is guessing words from context, and while a few hints to evolutions of that mechanic appear, none are explored. This could be forgiven for a good enough plot, but it's just... fine. There are no twists. Everything goes pretty much as you think it will and is executed competently but not exceptionally.

Has the makings of something great,  but ultimately falls short. There should be a bit of a hint option,  some of the puzzles require help. Also very short. A longer version with deeper story would be great.
Loved the evolving story.

With the amount of "puzzle" games in the store that hand-feed you the answers, or prompt you for a hint after being idle for 3 seconds, this game was sooo refreshing! Challenging, thought-provoking, and extremely satisfying when figuring out the answers. Anyone complaining about this game were probably expecting the types of games mentioned above, and have no patience or problem solving skills (on the occasions I got stuck I left the game for a little while, came back refreshed, and managed to get through). Absolutely loved it, and the Orwellian feel was so interesting. Please make more games like this!

It was entertaining enough to play to the end but never did anything terribly exciting with the mechanics. It was too short, and too rushed, to make any connection with the personalities in the game. It should have been the sort of thing I love, but in the end it was just OK.
waste of money. cant type 'demanding' in one of the pages. pls fix. did not pay just to encounter a lame bug

It's fun but I think it's bugged out. I can't get past this level where she describes her boss being picky and I know the censored word was 'demanding" because it makes sense and I looked up a walk through but it doesn't work! I've tried every reasonable word for that particular phrase and I can't get past it!
Remenicent of old adventure games except this one tests your knowledge of the English language and attention to details
Some real head scratchers, but I always figured out them eventually. So well designed, you should play it.
I really enjoyed this short but fairly challenging adventure. Some of the puzzles towards the end seem impossible but with patience you can achieve any of them. I hope there are more games like it.
I love this game! I just wish O could sync it between my phone and tablet!

An interesting concept for a narrative experience with nothing mechanical to support it. Guessing blindly doesn't really qualify as a mechanic. The possibility space is too broad, and the result isn't really what could be called interactive since it is hard to become invested in a crapshoot. The narrative and prose, at least to where I stopped didn't wow, and are deficient in any real mechanical guidance. Ultimately, this is likely a premise better as an idea than a game, in this form or any other.

Average. I don't feel too annoyed over the price I paid for it, but it's nothing special, and the story is good at first but winds up a little cheesy. Some of the puzzle answers are near-impossible to guess, which wasn't fun. Overall, not awful, not amazing.
Good idea but when u r stuck...there is recourse
No way too really solve the puzzles except guessing. Just go read a walkthrough.
Rubbish story

Blackbar is an interesting idea. The 1984-esque setting is suitably creepy with its totalitarian vibe and vintage presentation. The premise is interesting and though limited manages to convey the narrative effectively and makes the game somewhat addictive.  There are a few issues I have with Blackbar though. For one, I found the play length to be too short. With this kind of premise you could easily have a chapter type design with each chapter telling a different story set in the same world, or one developing story from different character point of views. Right now the story of Vi and Kenty feels like one piece of a larger, missing puzzle.  Secondly, more to do with the gameplay itself, I found some of the puzzles to be unnecessarily hard - in particular 'Subculturia' sticks out as something that I never would have thought to guess! Challenge in a game is a good thing, but so is remembering that players don't have all the pieces of the puzzle like the developers do.  Overall, I enjoyed playing through Blackbar despite the short length and disappointing ending (underwhelming and too 'fairytale') but can't give 5 stars based on what this game could have been yet falls short of.
Though a bit short, i loved every minute of it. The story and the atmosphere were simply amazing.

Games only mechanic is to guess words which have been censored. Neither plot nor lore are worth the price for me. I admit, I've bought it without research at all. I was hoping to get experience like Dark Room. And mechanics included could give it to me. Unfortunately, they didn't grip me at all.

A good and innovative concept, however if you got stuck on anything, that was it. You either had to keep staring at the puzzle hoping you'd come up with a word you hadnt tried yet, or you had to look it up on line (something i hate doing). And some of the words were pretty tough!
Rubbish to be totally frank, its so short.... Feel completely robbed
Really had me thinking, but way too short, and the end was so anticlimatic.

I enjoyed it. Never played a game like it. It was long enough and I liked the ending. You have no impact on the outcome, you're strictly along for the ride, but it's an interesting ride. The sense of gleeful malice emanating from The Department is horrific, and at times a little jarring.

Lets make a rubbish script that makes no sense, blank out half the words and then pay people to try and work it out. Cheated my way through to see how it ended and was awful. Made it under refund time thank gos
Well executed and thought provoking. But I was all set for a few plot twists which never arrived!
If you like puzzles and intuitive post-orwellian storytelling, you'll love it. _____ the depa_____t!

I really enjoyed the gameplay, and the narrative was engaging and enjoyable (could be improved). As others have said, the ending is ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà. It really lets the whole experience ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà, ended too ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà and feels like a ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà of money. I hope the developers take this on board and make it amazing (I'm already seeing  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà in the store so fix it quick!) Also the game would put the last typed answer into the next ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà which was ann‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà.
Was just getting into it and it ended so suddenly with such a weird anticlimax...
This game is one of the most amazing game I ever seen on Android platform. Really exciting about future update on this game.
Frustrating at ? Listening Department.
Kind of like mad libs. I hope there'll be another story on the way, it didn't last long enough.
Great idea for a game
Not worth the time invested.  Story is bland and predictable.
Was such a pity
Too short. Need an update. New story?

I'm sorry, but I'm quite perplexed as to why this game has received so many positive reviews.  The ending made me hate myself a little for being suckered into purchasing something that really offers nothing.  However, to be fair, I suppose there isn't really a "better" way to end this type of game.
The ending let me down, but a fantastic game! So different and it had me hooked for days.
Punchy interesting game that fell flat and meaningless at the end.

There are three different personalities unfolding at the same time. To figure out the missing word, sometimes you have to consider the personality. The game never requires any cultural orientation. For example the hidden word is not going to be "lorry" vs "truck" unless a clue has been given. Several times I got stuck in the game, and I would just take a couple days and mull the problem. Eventually I would get the flash of insight. I don't think the game was too short. The game has to end sometime.
The gameplay was good, but it was way too short and predictable. Not worth $2. It would be good as a free, ad-supported app.
Definitely a good game, however the ending was terrible, and the gameplay could be better. Needs to be longer at the very least, or even have a less obvious storyline.
Proof that there are still new ideas out there, and that alone is worth the asking price.

I enjoyed trying to figure everything out. A couple words I had to look up. I felt for paying for the game, it could have been longer and the ending was crap. Wish there would have been more details about the ending.

Very interesting idea which is well-executed for the most part. I did feel that some of the letters had very vague answers to them with no logical way of discerning what the missing words could have been. That did detract from my overall enjoyment of the game, but other than that, it's a chilling story that kept me hooked.
I enjoyed this game and thought it was quite a clever idea, if a little short. Interested to see what this development team does next.

The story is OK at best, but doesn't actually go anywhere.  If you don't know a word, you're essentially stuck as there is no kind of hint system. You can look up a walkthrough online, but it kind of ruins the game. This should be handled in-game. Very short as well.  Could also use a black background and white text option in order to save battery.

Gameplay is unique and well executed. Puzzles are hard without being impossible. Brilliant atmosphere and engrossing story. Ending is one of the least satisfying I've ever encountered - wanted to scream it was so lame.

An incredibly inventive title that should have a lot more downloads than it's currently sitting on.   For me, thematically, it's preaching to the choir, but that's what I love about it - Blackbar feels like it was made solely for me. If nothing else, I know there's at least another two people out there that feel the way I do about the way things are heading, and the importance of being coherent and uninhibited in our speech and communications.  Blackbar says more in a couple of hours than most can muster in a day filled to the brim with tweets, status updates, and photos of lunch. Docile indeed. 5/5
A riveting story and really pushing my word knowledge already. Wonderful and easy to pick up when I have a moment to continue.

This game isn't bad, and the basic game mechanic is quite clever. The other aspects just don't quite hold up to the same level. I would have liked a few "normal" letters by way of a tutorial, and for me, the puzzles ranged from entirely intuitive (went too fast) to "how in heck was I supposed to figure that out?" in difficulty (the latter I consulted a guide for so I could continue the story). Pleased with my purchase more in hopes of seeing future games from this dev than due to good value on this one.
A witty, cleverly designed text noir.
read, guess, enter, repeat if you have no idea what the word is... that IS the game.
Words in text are redacted, and you type what you think is missing. If you're correct, you advance to the next word.
Funny, insightful, and moving, especially the end. And it's fun, too. Android needs more games like this.
Engrossing and brilliant! I just wish it was longer!

Very good concept and like the minimalist. Some more expansion on the setting i.e. year, how the department come to power etc. would possibly be beneficial to the "feel" of the game. Definitely recommended.
This is a wonderful commentary on the effects of mass surveillance and censorship disguised as a word puzzle game.
I got as far as the upside down page, then it would not let me enter any text- click on the black bar and nothing happens.  Guess I'll never be able to finish the game. Waste of money!

The atmosphere here is fantastic. Some of the answers gave me chills as I realised what the 'Department of Communication' had censored in a given letter, and why. That being said, the fiction isn't handled especially delicately, and certainly once a decidedly human (if sadistic) relationship develops directly between you and the censor, some of that creepy detachment is lost.  Secondly, I was very surprised at how short and linear this game was, given it's a paid title.  All in all a lovely gaming experience I'm glad I had, but did feel a little disappointed at the end. 3/5
Buggy

Really enjoyed this game, the story is a great framework to set up a series of word puzzles that don't feel shoe horned in - some of them are a bit tricky, but they give you that "I'm clever' buzz that you get from all the best puzzle games. (Saying that, I did have to look up one of the answers )
Would have given 5 stars if the game had been longer. Seems a bit too short for the price.
Excellent mix of word game and dystopian fiction. If you like either,  play it.

This game is interesting, but I keep having trouble deleting the first in a word without first switching input boxes. Some of pieces are just guesswork. How many hours were they in class? Keep guessing!

If the phrase "dystopian science fiction word puzzles" doesn't do anything for you, then neither I nor anything in this world can do anything to help you not be a boring garbage person. Good luck with sucking; sucking isn't my scene. That's why I played and enjoyed Blackbar.  Full Disclosure: I am a very cool person with good opinions.
Just finished the game. Blown away. An absolute gem of a game. A proper brain teaser with an interesting story.
Utterly compelling
Stay away from this game. The idea sounds intriguing, but the execution is severely lacking.

The story for this story is compelling and for the first many pages, there is a certain satisfaction and figuring out the puzzle. This then rapidly devolves into very abstract puzzles that mostly result in trial and error to advance the story. I eventually just looked up the answers so I could proceed with the story and once you do that, there's essentially no game left.
SEQUEL WHEN

Driven by good story that make you want to play and try to advance to the next pages. A bit too hard (as I'm using English as my 2nd language) if there are some hints like word list or giving away some first alphabet in the field

For a game that has one mechanic, text entry, entering text is clunky and awkward.  Clues are minimal, most of the 'puzzles' are solved by trial and error, which only compounds the frsutrating experience of selecting/editing text. And to add insult to injury, the price is exorbitant.  Very cool story and idea crippled by poor implementation.
